content.webTitle: 'A minority within a minority': celebrating queer artists of colour

fields.headline: 'A minority within a minority': celebrating queer artists of colour
fields.bodyText: It’s pride month, which means gay culture is at the forefront all over the world. But beyond the rainbow flag emoji, there’s one art exhibition in San Diego that digs beneath the surface to shine light on what the curator calls: “A minority within a minority.” Opening on 29 June at the San Diego Art Institute, Forging Territories: Queer Afro and Latinx Contemporary Art showcases the works of 20 regional LGBTQ artists who have been overlooked in some way or another. “It’s either overlooked or there’s some kind of tokenism, it doesn’t feel substantial,” said the curator, Rubén Esparza. “It’s essential we get our voices out there, otherwise you don’t tell the full LGBTQ story, it’s only one-sided. It’s the broader story of minorities we need to tell.” The exhibition covers three territories: social and political issues, everyday lives and identity, to find out “who we are as black and brown people”, said Esparza. It came about as an extension of the Queer Biennial, which Esparza, a Los Angeles-based Chicano artist, founded in 2012 (the biennial launches its fourth edition next summer). “I started the queer biennial because we weren’t seeing ourselves out there,” said Esparza. “Excuse my crudeness, but I just said to myself: ‘Shut the fuck up and do something about it.’ I’m not one to sit back. I’m not going to wait for someone to invite me to be a part of something. I’m going to do it myself.” The San Diego exhibit includes the works of photographer Laura Aguilar, who shows portraits of nude queer women, including herself, among nature. The artist, who passed away last year, has been noted for capturing her subjects with “frank empathy and humanism”. “She celebrates people in the margins, not polished airbrushed people we see everywhere today,” said Esparza. “It’s her and her body and her friends, not these archetypal supermodels, there’s beauty in that.” “She inspired me with her diligence and despite the fact that she could barely afford to live, she made prints, editions … she never stopped making work,” he adds. There’s also the works of performance artist and activist Patrisse Cullors, a photographer who co-founded the Black Lives Matter movement and whose photography was crucial to include, as much of LGBT art that makes its way to the mainstream is by white men. “There’s a lot of great art and stories to tell, we’re forging that territory,” said Esparza. Carlos Almaraz, a Mexican American painter who was a pioneer of the Chicano street art movement, is showing The Struggle of Mankind, a work from 1989 which shows an act of violence. There are also works by Maurice Harris, a photographer who puts black subjects alongside intricate floral arrangements. “They’re a celebration of the African American diaspora,” said Esparza. “When we see people of color in the news, there’s usually some kind of turmoil, but Maurice is countering that with these beautiful black folks in beautiful settings, an antidote to the poison out there.” Then there’s Nao Bustamante, whose work celebrates the women who fought in the Mexican Revolution from 1910 and beyond, as soldiers who fought during the civil war, as well as nurses who took care of others. “It’s celebrating the women; documenting these women,” said Esparza. “It’s not really recorded and there were hard-hitting women from that time.” The exhibition opening falls on the same week as the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots, where the LGBT community fought against police raids of New York City’s Stonewall Inn in 1969. However, the artists here are based in California, so there are references to historic gay activism on the west coast. That includes the Black Cat riots, where the Black Cat Tavern gay bar in Los Angeles held the country’s first gay rights protest in 1967, and the rarely remembered Cooper Do-nuts riot from 1959 in Los Angeles, where the gay and trans community rioted against police harassment at a 24-hour Cooper Do-nuts cafe. “I want to make sure we bring the whole spectrum and respect the people of color in the queer community, it’s important to have that balance,” said Esparza. “Once in a while, it’s great to bring together brown and black people where people connect and see something in each other and create great friendships. These exhibitions are builders of great community. I’m just doing my part to tell those stories and push those stories out.” • This article was amended on 21 June 2019 to correct a suggestion in the first paragraph that the exhibition was on display in San Francisco rather than San Diego.
